page.title: 03Plants on the South Downs
page.content:
Sheep Grazing is mostly responsible for the short grass on the Downland. It is possible to find up to thirty different species of plants in one square metre of turf. Chalk soils are generally rather shallow often little more than 20 cm deep.
The three most plentiful grasses of chalk downland turf are sheep's fescue,brome and carnation sedge. Salad burnet,rough hawkbit,mouse _ ear hawkweed and stemless thistles are among the commonest plants found on the calcium rich soils. Also the three yellow flowered members of the pea family,bird foot trefoil,horseshoe, vetch and kidney vetch grow there too. In spring orchids are common.
